titleStmt.title: File Drawer Report: A Preliminary Test of Video-Mediated Severe Weather Exposure and Note on the Potential Role of Mindfulness in Decreasing Storm-Associated Negative Affect

affiliation.orgName: College of Education and Social Services
U.S. National Weather Service Forecast Office

analytic.title: File Drawer Report: A Preliminary Test of Video-Mediated Severe Weather Exposure and Note on the Potential Role of Mindfulness in Decreasing Storm-Associated Negative Affect

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Research at the intersection of meteorology and societal impacts is increasingly important. Still, it is relatively rare for this work to take on a psychological frame. Here, we blend media and positive psychology topics with the judgement and decision-making domain for a multifaceted investigation into psychological and behavioral responses to severe and dangerous weather conditions. Using a simple pre/post, quasi-experimental design, we tested the following predictions: 1) Exposure to dangerous weather conditions, via video-based multimedia, would increase participants' negative affect and weather-related fear; 2) video-mediated storm exposure would increase participants' intent to engage in future protective actions; and 3) a brief mindfulness exercise would significantly lower the weather-induced negative affectivity. Resource unavailability meant we were unable to conduct a full experiment including a control group. However, all three hypotheses were confirmed and we believe our findings warrant further replication. Results indicated a small but significant (apparent) effect of mindfulness in reducing negative affect when controlling for lived storm experience and positive affect brought on by storm-associated awe and excitement (2 = 0.02), and small to moderate effects of multimedia exposure on increases in protective action intentions (d =-0.71), and weather fear (d =-0.24). Results are discussed in light of meteorological communication principles, the existing literatures on mindfulness and protective action responses to severe weather, and the potential for mindfulness interventions in psychological responses to severe and dangerous weather.

div.head: File Drawer Report: A Preliminary Test of Video-Mediated Severe Weather Exposure and
Note on the Potential Role of Mindfulness in Decreasing Storm-Associated Negative Affect
div.p: The forecasting of severe and, especially, dangerous weather is a core function facilitated by meteorologists, many of whom work directly for the protection of life and property. Much attention has concordantly been paid to the practical aspects of forecasting and the atmosphere's physical mechanisms (e.g., Corfidi et al., 2015;Thompson et al., 2017;Potvin, 2019). Still, there is an inherently human aspect to the field of meteorology even as it has traditionally emphasized physical science and enters into an unprecedentedly digital, tech-driven era (Argyle et al., 2020;Doswell, 2004;Karstens et al., 2018;Murphy, 1993;Wilson et al., 2016Wilson et al., , 2019Wilson et al., , 2020. In fact, it is partially due to weather data consumers' technology reliance that physical process-oriented research is making space for social impacts work (Stuart et al., 2022).

While most societal impacts work in meteorology focuses on improving theoretical models of weather communication and understanding society-nature interactions, one area recognizes that individual differences research can provide important insights alongside sociologically-oriented inquiry. Psycho-behavioral researchers seek to answer questions about individual reactions and responses to sanguine as well as more dangerous weather conditions.

Topics include but are not limited to forecast uncertainty (e.g., Grounds & Joslyn, 2018;Joslyn & Savelli, 2010;Joslyn & LeClerc, 2012;LeClerc & Joslyn, 2012), extreme weather risk perception (e.g., Allan et al., 2020;Krocak et al., 2020;Ripberger et al., 2020), hurricane evacuation (e.g., Allen et al., 2020;Stewart, 2011Stewart, , 2015, and more general uses of weather information (Bolton, Blumberg et al., 2020;Stewart, 2009;Stewart et al., 2012). Much of this work can be practically applied to vulnerable populations (Bolton et al., 2021;Lazrus et al., 2012;Sherman-Morris et al., 2020).

As it relates to weather fears and phobias, however, the literature has remained sparse since John Westefeld first introduced the term "severe weather phobia" in 1996. His work paved the way forward with early sub-clinical and clinical descriptions of phobias related to severe thunderstorms, and tornadoes more particularly. Westefeld recounts his earliest encounters with storm-phobic individuals in the 1980s as including descriptions of fear manifesting through "…early anticipation and hypervigilance concerning severe weather… that is to say, near constant monitoring of the weather…" (1996, p. 509), increased anxiety for "any hint of severe weather… even 5-7 days in the future" (1996, p. 510), and "…a massive increase in anxiety, including, at times, an unwillingness to go anywhere that was perceived by the individual as 'unsafe'" (1996, p. 510). His 1996 paper discusses a small study (81 participants) which further confirmed these tendencies and cast a brighter light on the phenomenon.

In the wake of these findings, there has been a relative dearth of storm anxiety research and a considerable amount of theorizing and formulation. Academic scholars are focused, in part, on creating a more theoretically-inclined knowledgebase by which to understand psychometeorological difficulties, including but not limited to storm anxiety. Stewart (2007aStewart ( , 2007b provided an Adlerian Individual Psychology perspective by which to understand human-weatherclimate interactions; Weintrobe (2012), among others, provided a generally psychoanalytic/dynamic perspective on climate change, and Bolton and colleagues have theorized from the vantage point of emotion-focused, Adlerian, acceptance and commitment, and person-centered psychotherapy (Bolton, Stewart, & Mogil, 2020a, Bolton, Stewart, & Mogil, 2020b.

Severe thunderstorm phobias and anxieties have largely been the focus of cognitivebehavioral therapy practitioners and researchers (Barkham & Hobson, 1989;Coleman et al., 2014;Greening & Dollinger, 1992;Lonigan et al., 1994;Matthey, 1988;Watt & DiFrancesantonio, 2012;Westefeld, 1996;Westefeld et al., 2006). These scholars have also treated seasonal affective disorder (Rohan et al., 2004;Rohan et al., 2007;Rohan et al., 2015;Terman et al., 2023) and winter storm phobias (Wang, 2000). Mason (2010) examined severe weather phobia in a small sample of high school students who had experienced weather events defined as "traumatic." Brodeur-St. James 2010implicated posttraumatic stress-specific cognitions, anxiety sensitivity, and degrees of weather condition exposure in a larger college student sample of 815 people (though see DiFrancesantonio, 2012, for relevant discussion). More recently, Ernst and colleagues (Ernst et al., 2020) examined the affective experiences of people during storm events, and Kraft and Grant (2023) investigated weather-related attentional biases in a psychophysiological study of event-related potentials.
Most relevant to the work discussed hereafter is a paper authored by Westefeld et al. (2006), inquiring about the psychological and physical responses of storm-phobic individuals.

Unlike even more devastating weather events, such as hurricanes, which often involve post-event trauma (Acierno et al., 2007), the most commonly-reported response to feelings of storm phobia and anxiety, for most people, including 81.29% of the sample recruited by Westefeld et al., is constant monitoring of television, radio, or the internet for up-to-date weather information during storm events. This byproduct of individuals' increased anxiety correlates with the way people often seek confirmation of storm or hazard activity before taking protective action (Jauernic & Van Den Broeke, 2016;Jon et al., 2019;Lindell & Perry, 2012). Such information-seeking could, in turn, lead to greater storm exposure Stewart, 2009;Jon et al., 2019;Stewart et al., 2012;Stewart & Bolton, 2023).

div.head: The Present Study
div.p: Motivated by Westefeld and colleagues' 2006 findings, we designed a small study to add to the overarching meteorology-psychology, and specific psycho-behavioral-meteorological, literatures. Although we did not explicitly frame the study within a news media context or with respect to the monitoring of severe weather conditions, we tested three predictions surrounding people's psychological and behavioral responses in the face of severe and dangerous weather conditions (SDWC) via the use of a short video, not overly dissimilar to that which might be aired by news media during or following a severe weather event. Since weather may be severe in a meteorological sense but not dangerous to humans (e.g., a tornado over open farmland;
flooding in a river where people are not in close proximity), we explicitly use SDWC to indicate that the weather in our video is both severe and poses a threat to human life.

Our hypotheses emphasize the potential for exposure to severe weather to induce negative affect, or emotionality, and to increase fear of weather. Second, we are concerned with the potential for such exposure to increase intentions to engage in future protective actions-a positive side effect of increased fear and also a side effect of enhanced experiential knowledge of the dangers of storms. Third, we are concerned with the possibility that a brief mindfulness exercise can reduce severe weather-induced negative affect. We thus predicted each of these: That exposure to severe weather multimedia increases negative affect, weather fear, and future protective action intentions, and that mindfulness has utility in reducing any such increase in negative affect. Before continuing with our methodology and results, we will next introduce the topic of mindfulness.

div.head: Mindfulness
div.p: Mindfulness has many beneficial effects on mental and physical health (Hölzel et al., 2011). Its forms are myriad; commonly, the premise of Vipassana meditation, attending to one's present-moment experiencing of inner thoughts, feelings, sensations, and external environment with intention and without judgement (Kabat-Zinn, 2006), is extrapolated to all of them.

Breathing is key to meditative practice; focusing on one's breathing (e.g., noticing in-breaths and out-breaths) helps to center attention and lower heart rate and blood pressure. Thus immersed, participants are encouraged to notice, without judgment or reaction, the thoughts and feelings diverting attention from breathing. They are encouraged to observe and adopt an attitude of acceptance towards their cognitions and sensations and simply let them exist.

Regular mindfulness practice leads to more conscious (vs. automatic) responding to events. This allows, in a clinical context, for the modification of misperceptions and negative appraisals, while increasing cognitive flexibility and positive affect (Carlson, 2015). A recent systematic review found that brief mindfulness interventions (as short as 5 minutes and one session) yielded positive health outcomes related to anxiety, depression, emotion regulation, thinking, and stress (Howarth et al., 2019). The 2-minute guided mindfulness exercise used in this study directed participants to focus on their breath, acknowledge and mindfully observe-but not act on-any thoughts or physical sensations they might be feeling, and to imagine how they wanted the rest of their day to go once the meditation ended.

div.head: Participants
div.p: An international convenience sample (United States: 101; United Kingdom: 12; Canada: 5; unspecified Other: 20; 1 unreported) consisting of 139 volunteer participants was recruited on social media (Facebook: 62; Reddit: 32) and from Saint Leo University (42) or personal contacts
(3) for participation in a Qualtrics-hosted survey. The participants-103 women (74.64%), 31 men, and 4 non-binary individuals-were 98 European-American, 12 African-American, 11

Asian, 8 bi-or multi-racial, 2 Hispanic, 1 Latino/a, and 6 non-specified individuals. Their mean age was 34.57 (standard deviation, SD = 12.95; range: 18-74). Note, 1 person each did not report country, race, and gender, and 2 did not report age. Fifty-three (38.13%) participants selfreported considering weather observation or study a hobby; 10 (7.19%) had some degree of formal meteorology training. Seventy-five participants (76.5%) reported experiencing a severe weather event they would consider dangerous; the mean number of experiences per person was 2.14. Thus, most participants had SDWC experience and at least some had experience with weather observation on a more formal basis than perhaps the average person.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: The participants first completed a standard set of demographic items (as reported above, except education and state of residence for U.S. respondents, provided in the open dataset). They then watched videos and responded to Likert scale-based questionnaires to assess negative and positive affect, otherwise referred to as emotionality (13 items from the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule, Short Form, PANAS-SF; Watson et al., 1988), 14 items from the second author's unpublished Weather Risk-taking Scale (WRTS), and 11 items from his unpublished Fear of Weather Scale (FOWS). The self-report measures were scored on agreement-(affect and fear) and likelihood-based (protective action), Likert-type scales; the affect items from 1-5 (max score 50), protective action from 1-7 (max score 98), and weather fear from 1-7 (recoded 0-6, max score 66).

Although our affect-related focus was on negativity (i.e., trait adjectives including distressed, agitated, upset, disturbed, scared, irritable, dazed, stunned, nervous, jittery), we included 3 positive adjectives (excited, interested, enthusiastic) which might relate to mental states important to weather exposure, weather-induced awe (Gordon et al., 2017), and curiosity and which would serve as distractor variables to help mitigate participants focusing only on negativity. The 14 WRTS items related to behaviors in which one would engage prior to and during severe weather; we selected items believed to reflect everyday encounters with SDWC (e.g., "drive through water that is flowing across the highway," "remain outside when a thunderstorm is overhead").

The 11 fear-based items consisted of particular weather and environmental events including, for example, "dark clouds," "heavy rain," "thunderstorms," and "driving or riding in a motor vehicle during strong and/or gusting winds." The affective items were administered at three time points in the survey, with two contextual frames instructing participants to respond in certain ways; once for a trait measurement to assess general affective tendencies and twice to assess state, or present-moment, affective states immediately prior to and following the severe weather video and mindfulness intervention. 1 The weather fear and protective action items were administered twice, in trait and state forms. Cronbach's alpha (α; Boslaugh, 2012) values indicated all measures were reliable. 2

After the demographics, scale-based items and video stimuli were presented in the following order: Trait affect, protective actions, and weather fear; SDWC video; pre-mindfulness state affect; mindfulness intervention; post-mindfulness state affect; and state-based postprotective action or weather fear (both presented, but randomized to prevent order effects). All participants, finally, were presented with the item about lived experiences of SDWC. This procedure was approved by the Saint Leo University Institutional Review Board.

div.head: Data Analysis Plan
div.p: The video stimuli in the quasi-experiment were a short, 3-minute montage of SDWC scenes and a brief, 2-minute guided mindfulness exercise. 3 The data were analyzed with a planned repeated-measures analysis of covariance (ANCOVA; for affect, reflecting the use of trait and two state data points), with five covariates to control for lived experiences of near-miss cloud-ground lightning strikes; strong, property-damaging winds; severe and dangerous flooding; damaging hail; and tornadoes-the elements witnessed in the video collage-and with two planned paired-sample, student t-tests for protective action intentions and weather fear. 4 Note that these were explicitly conducted as one-tailed significance tests of the null hypothesis that trait 2 0.86 (trait negative affect), 0.68 (trait protective action), 0.92 (pre negative affect), 0.89 (post negative affect), 0.89 (post positive affect), 0.71 (post protective action), and 0.94 (post weather fear). Typically, Cronbach α scores have a standard of acceptability beginning at 0.70. Thus, trait protective action responses were marginally reliable in this study. However, the lower value is due to item functioning properties we acknowledge-some were necessarily reverse-coded, and reversed items naturally lower reliability when combined with regular items-rather than some statistical anomaly. We accepted this lower reliability to ensure a greater breadth of content for the measurement of protective action.
protective action and weather fear were not lower than post-test protective action and weather fear. Outlying data points ± 2.5 SD from the mean were removed before analysis began.

For the ANCOVA, we report generalized eta-squared ( 2 ; Bakeman, 2005;Olejnik & Algina, 2003), power, and planned repeated contrasts which compared the affect measurements in trait-pre and pre-post pairs (these include Dunn-Bonferroni confidence intervals; CI). For the t-tests we report Cohen's d (J. Cohen, 1988), representing the standardized mean difference between pre-and post-measurement scores, and CI for the weather fear mean difference.
We also report normality checks (Mauchly's test of sphericity, represented by ε, with a statistical correction for the ANCOVA; and Shapiro-Wilk tests, represented by ω, for the t-tests;

Fields, 2017). Generalized eta-squared ( 2 ) and d, ranging from 0-1, measure the amount of standardized difference between means. Power, also ranging from 0-1, represents the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis and thus detecting a true statistical effect (Boslaugh, 2012). Dunn-Bonferroni confidence intervals are assessed at the 95% level and here estimate the range in which the value of the variable being computed could be expected to fall if a study were conducted multiple times with the same sample size drawn from the same population (Boslaugh, 2012).

div.head: Affect
div.p: Mauchly's test revealed non-normal variance (ε = 0.76, p < 0.001), so we applied a Huyn-Feldt sphericity estimate to correct the degrees of freedom. The ANCOVA showed a significant decrease in participants' ratings of negative affect after controlling for the effects of lived experience with the aforementioned SDWC, and for the additive effect of positive affect: F(1.52, 136.70) = 15.12, (MTraitAffect=18.64, SD = 5.93; MPreAffect=19.42, SD = 7.95;

MPostAffect=12.57, SD = 3.98) p = 0.02, power = 1, 2 = 0.02. No covariates were significant. Contrast analyses revealed a significant difference between pre-and post, but not trait and post, affect ratings. This provides confidence that the video reliably induced the desired response, since the baseline and post-exposure measurements should not differ. The contrastassociated, bootstrap-estimated marginal means (simulating 1,000 instances based on the study's sample parameters to allow inference of the means in other studies with the same parameters) were 16.63 CI [13.90,20.39]) and 9.80 CI [7.47,13.15]), t = 11.38, p < 0.001.

div.head: Protective Action Intentions
div.p: The protective action data were non-normally distributed (ω = 0.97, p < 0.001). Due to the central limit theorem, the Shapiro-Wilk test is generally robust against statistical assumption violations in sample sizes exceeding ~30 people (Fields, 2017;Razali & Wah, 2011). However, since the non-normal distribution violates CI statistical assumptions, we do not report them for this result. The paired-sample t-test showed a significant increase (Figure 2

div.head: Weather Fear
div.p: Normality testing on the weather fear data revealed a normal distribution (ω = 1, p = 0.99). The paired-sample t-test showed a significant increase (Figure 3 Note that the directionality of the t-test means and d scores indicate the extent to which the first, trait-based measurement is less than the second, post-test measurement; it does not mean, for example, that there exists a negative statistical relationship, as in correlation, or that the effect is weak. The upper-bound CI represents the maximum mean difference weather fear score that could be obtained with this study's sample characteristics (the lower bound is not relevant for one-tailed significance tests).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: This quasi-experimental study was the first, so far as we are aware, to test relationships between SDWC multimedia exposure and negative emotions and the potential efficacy of a brief mindfulness intervention in alleviating negative affect after such exposure. Given the potential for severe weather to excite people (Gordon et al., 2017), that emotions can be difficult to elicit in survey research (Siedlecka & Denson, 2019), and potential interactions between the prevalence of severe weather experiences and the heterogeneity of weather itself, there was some question as to whether our video would reliably induce effects of increased negative emotionality, weather fear, and protective action intentions.

We found significant increases from baseline trait affect to pre-mindfulness and post-SDWC-exposure state affect; and decreases from pre-to post-mindfulness state affect. We also successfully rejected the null hypothesis that trait protective action intentions and weather fear were not greater than post-test protective action intentions and weather fear. Thus, our findings seem to indicate that SDWC multimedia exposure portends significant increases in protective action intentions and weather fear from baseline trait to post-exposure state measurements.

Although we were unable to test our mindfulness intervention against a control group with, for example, a muscle relaxation exercise, there was a decrease in negative affectivity, potentially due to the intervention, even in the presence of participants' lived experiences with severe and dangerous weather. That this decrease was present with weather-related excitement and SDWC experience-related variance accounted for would seem to suggest that the intervention played a role. While it is possible that the mere passage of time alleviated negative affectivity, the presentation order of our survey (SDWC video; pre-mindfulness state affect; mindfulness intervention; post-mindfulness state affect) was such that participants might indeed have benefited from the intervention.

The prevalence of SDWC experience in the sample suggests, to us, two things about the reliability of our induction and the possibility that the negative affect it produced was reduced by the mindfulness intervention. First, if the intervention did not work, it seems reasonable to suggest that there should not have been a decrease in negative affectivity. Actually living through a dangerous weather event and then either cueing a memory of it or imagining or witnessing a similar situation would in theory activate a stronger attentional response and associated negativity which would persist regardless of attempts to shift one's mind away from such thinking, especially with repeated exposure (Contractor et al., 2018) and if experience of the event was deeply internalized or the event was particularly traumatic (Cisler et al., 2009;Kraft & Grant, 2023;Mason, 2010). While we cannot know the participants' inner experiences of their lived events (for further discussion on the matter of weather and climate as personallyexperienced events, see Brügger et al., 202l;Stewart & Blau, 2019;Stewart & Oh, 2019;Stewart & Bolton, 2023), it is reasonable to suggest that their negative reactions were real but not so heightened as to be irreducible.

Second (and speaking to the reliability of the video induction), given the preponderance of lived weather experiences and apparent weather knowledge in this sample, one can alternatively argue that participants might have been desensitized by their real-world storm experiences and had less of an affective reaction, which in turn would have ameliorated the reaction sooner (e.g., Casteel, 2023;Jon et al., 2019). Indeed, in a majority-Canadian sample, most participants were found to have experienced a severe and dangerous weather event but not to be overly fearful of severe weather . Such desensitization does not seem as likely here since, if it existed, it might have mitigated the post-exposure negative affect increase in the first place. One who has many experiences of a thing does not typically experience it with the same vividness every time (Campbell et al., 2014). At the least, these are some factors to consider within this research. In light of these points, the SDWC video seems to have reliably induced weather fear and the mindfulness intervention appears to have played some role in decreasing the negative affectivity observed for our participants following video-mediated storm exposure. This, of course, warrants further research with a proper control group and other SDWC stimuli.

Although personal experience is always subjective and severity of weather events varies and can impact people differently and quite extensively, our data suggests that people experience fear with an accompanying increase in the desire to engage protective actions towards weather hazards upon exposure to storm-related weather multimedia. Hence, a more sensitive balance might be sought between enough fear-induction to create planning for protective action and less catastrophic weather montages such as those used in this study, to avoid panic.

Mindfulness, further, may be a useful tool for those negatively affected by a variety of severe and dangerous weather conditions. This may be particularly true when memories of lived events arise, but not necessarily in the aftermath of events, since event impacts vary so widely. In other words, mindfulness exercises may help if one experiences negative emotions following a tree falling in one's yard due to wind or rain, or after one is affected by minor hail or sees a nearby lightning strike, for example, but not following one's experience with a more volatile event such as driving along and witnessing a distant or nearby tornado. Further research, not only with control groups but also incorporating different kinds of meditation, should be conducted to reliably establish the efficacy of these practices.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: As with all studies conducted online, this one was subject to potential problems relating to the nature of participant self-report (e.g., Rosenman et al. 2011). One particular caveat to this work is that our severe weather stimulus was a video montage comprising multiple dangerous weather phenomena and, due to concerns about participant burden and fatigue, we did not ask participants which singular element scared them most. We therefore cannot begin to attribute the observed increases in negative affect or weather fear to any particular aspect of the video on its own. Even so, such an inference might still be inaccurate; basing affect and fear increases on the thing participants most fear would fail to properly respect the variance-explaining statistical contributions of the remaining elements (Fiedler, 2012;Grömping, 2007;Kass et al., 2016).

This method also cannot account for order or other effects induced by the static nature of the SDWC video stimuli. Only a more nuanced pre-post experimental design could properly account for accumulative effects across different types of weather hazard. The present design additionally cannot control for threats to internal validity that might occur in repeated-measures research without a control group, especially demand characteristics and related "good subject" biases-the participants intuiting the purpose of the post-test and responding in ways that support the hypothesis-or infer causality of findings.

Related to construct validity, there is some concern about the nature and strength of the 2minute mindfulness intervention; however, given that there were effects of video viewing with respect to all three of our hypotheses, we are confident that our method, chosen due to time constraints and other factors inherent to online studies, was at least minimally adequate. Furthermore, our sample was small and comprised mainly of White women. Greater gender and ethnic diversity are needed in a conceptual replication to reliably generalize any potential interpretations of these data. We need not just women and men but nonbinary, Asian, Black, Hispanic, and other persons as well if work in this area is to continue and be considered robust.
This study was intended as a first step, proof-of-concept endeavor in the area of individual differences, media psychology, and meteorological impacts upon society.

Finally, especially since participants were recruited internationally, it is important to consider that survey responses might have been moderated due to the quality of individual experiences with weather events. For example, tornadoes are rare in the U.K. (although they occur there with the highest frequency-per-land-unit-area in the world, averaging 33 per year; Fujita, 1973;Tornado and Storm Research Organisation, n.d.) and in Europe relative to the U.S. and Canada (Fujita, 1973), while hail and lightning storms are more frequent (Enno et al., 2020;Punge & Kunz, 2016) but even more widespread in the United States (Taszarek et al., 2020). A lack of relevant knowledge and/or first-hand experience may have enhanced negative affect beyond the variability-accounting ability of the lived experience covariate, whereas those with more knowledge and/or exposure may have been less fearful.

div.head: Conclusions and Future Work
div.p: The results of this study require replication. Nevertheless, among other take-aways, these tentative findings indicate meteorologists should be aware of the influence the presentation of storm footage, by news media and through other sources, may have on the general public's emotions. The public depends on meteorologists to communicate the severity and danger of weather conditions in an accurate and factual, but not overly fear-inducing, manner, and our results suggest that witnessing harmful weather events can be emotionally troubling.

One question that arises from this work relates to the emotional effects on viewers of "storm (horror) stories" frequently shown by national and local media outlets. Are they ultimately curiosity-inducing and educational, desensitizing, or phobia-inducing? The literature would benefit from attempts to answer such questions. Future work examining the temporal stability and reducibility of SDWC exposure-induced fear-which one might expect to be linked to different types of weather event, magnitude of the expected as well as the experienced event (did anticipation impact the actual experience?), length of its impact, and more person-relevant factors-would also be of benefit. MJB conceived, and MJB, AES, LKA, and SHH designed, the study. MJB and LKA analyzed the data. MJB was the primary manuscript author; writing support was provided by LKA (statistics), AES (method), MCW (mindfulness literature), SHH (meteorological subject expertise), and DRA (proofing). We are grateful to all who took part in the study. The study was conducted without funding, although MJB was supported academically by a Graduate Fellowship sponsored by the U.S. National Weather Service and awarded by the American Meteorological Society. The opinions, conclusions, and recommendations expressed here are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the views of the American Meteorological Society or National Weather Service. We have no conflicts of interest to declare.

figure.figDesc: All of these computation-supporting tests allow stronger inferences to be made from the data and are important for open science practices (Calin-Jageman & Cumming, 2016). Statistical analyses were conducted in the open-source JASP program (version 0.13.1, https://jaspstats.org/; Love et al. 2019). The post-hoc power analysis was conducted in the open-source G*Power program (version 3.1; Meyr et al., 2007). The 3 hypotheses were registered a priori, and open data are presently available, on the Open Science Framework website. 5 All procedures were approved by the Saint Leo University Institutional Review Board.

body.note: That is, for trait affect we asked, "To what extent do you usually feel each of the following; and for pre-and post-mindfulness state, "To what extent do you feel each of the following right now." For trait weather risk-taking, "In general, how likely is it that you would do the following," and for state, "After watching the weather video, how likely would you be to do the following?" For trait weather fear, "Listed below are different weather and related environmental events that can cause fear in people. Please rate how much fear you generally feel, in your everyday life, for each." For state, "After watching the weather video, how afraid are you of the following weather phenomena?"

The severe weather montage can be found at https://youtu.be/yaiNIZhQtD4 and the mindfulness video can be found at https://youtu.be/Jholcb8Gz0M.4 Participants were asked, "Have you ever experienced any of the following?"
The pre-registered hypotheses can be found at https://osf.io/7gn24, and the data (an open-source JASP file as well as an IBMformat SPSS file) at https://osf.io/7j6ma/.
